title: Which is correct: 'it was he', or 'it was him'? - Quora

response.answer_text: You should say “it was he”. The word “he” is the first person singular nominative pronoun. The pronouns are declined in the following manner: First personNominative sg. “I”Genitive sg. “mine”Dative sg. “me”Accusative sg. “me”Vocative sg. “I”Reflexive sg. “myself”Nominative pl. “we”Genitive pl. “ours”Dative pl. “us”Accusative pl. “us”Vocative pl. “we”Reflexive pl. “ourselves”Second personNominative sg. “you (used to be “thou”)”Genitive sg. “yours (used to be “thine”)”Dative sg. “you (used to be “thee”)”Accusative sg. “you (used to be “thee”)”Vocative sg. “you (used to be “thou”)”Reflexive sing. “yourself (used to be “thyself”)”Nominative pl. “you (used to be “ye”)”Genitive pl. “ours (used to be “yours”)”Dative pl. “you”Accusative pl. “you”Vocative pl. “you (used to be “ye”)”Reflexive pl. “yourselves”Third personNominative sg. “he/she/it”Genitive sg. “his/hers/its”Dative sg. “him/her/it”Accusative sg. “him/her/it”Vocative sg. “he/she/it”Reflexive sg. “himself/herself/itself”Nominative pl. “they”Genitive pl. “theirs”Dative pl. “them”Accusative pl. “them”Vocative pl. “they”Reflexive pl. “themselves”Now, the irregular verb “to be” (which is in fact found to be irregular in many tongues) is one of the verbs, which, when employed, does not take its “object” in the accusative case, as found in many tongues. Here is the verb conjugated (only in its indicative forms): Indicative Present tenseFirst person sg. “I am”Second person sg. “You are (used to be “thou art”)”Third person sg. “He/she/it is”First person pl. “We are”Second person pl. “You are”Third person pl. “They are”Imperfect tenseFirst person sg. “I used to be”Second person sg. “You used to be”Third person sg. “He/she/it used to be”First person pl. “We used to be”Second person pl. “You used to be”Third person pl. “They used to be”Perfect tenseFirst person sg. “I was”Second person sg. “You were (used to be “thou wast/thou wert”)”Third person sg. “He/she/it was”First person pl. “We were”Second person pl. “You were”Third person pl. “They were”Future tenseFirst person sg. “I will be”Second person sg. “You will be (used to be “thou wilt be”)”Third person sg. “He/she/it will be”First person pl. “We will be”Second person pl. “You will be”Third person pl. “They will be”Pluperfect tense (note: we find the majority of pluperfect tense contain the auxiliary verb “have” in its perfect tense + the perfect passive participle of the verb)First person sg. “I had been”Second person sg. “You had been (used to be ”thou hadst been”)”Third person sg. “He/she/it had been”First person pl. “We had been”Second person pl. “You had been”Third person pl. “They had been”Future perfect tenseFirst person sg. “I will have been”Second person sg. “You will have been (used to be “thou wilt have been”)”Third person sg. “He/she/it will have been”First person pl. “We will have been”Second person pl. “You will have been”Third person pl. “They will have been”Instead, the “object” remains in the nominative case, in whatever number in which it was originally found. e.g. when the phrase “you are he” is spoken, one would not change the “he” into its accusative form, *“you are him”. Herefore, If one desires to speak the phrase “it is he”, there is no need to transform the “he” into “him”. As a summarizing statement of what has been spoken, the phrase *“it was him” is incorrect, and instead one must employ the phrase “it was he”. To speak otherwise would be undoubtedly, unambiguously, wrong. This occurs as well in the Latin language: for example, direct your attention to this phrase, taken from Commentāriī dē Bellō Gallicō, Ea rēs est Helvētiīs per indicium ēnūntiāta, translated as “The affair was disclosed to the Helvetians through a notice”. The participle ēnūntiāta describes the noun rēs, “affair”, and thus matches its gender and number. However, it is still in the nominative case, even though it follows the verb est “to be”. Here is another example, from the Aeneid: huic coniūnx Sychaeus erat, meaning “Sychaeus was her spouse”. It is plain to see that the subject Sychaeus and the “object” of the verb erat (“(he) used to be”), coniūnx are both nominative. It here follows that, as in the majority of spoken tongues, the case of the “object” of the verb “to be” does not take the accusative case.

“It was him” is clearly what any native speaker would say if they hadn’t been scared by made-up rules invented by people who think language ought to be logical. In your sentence, “him” is what’s called the complement of the verb to be. In languages that have proper case systems, the complement in such a sentence is in the nominative case, that is, the case of the subject. English has for the most part lost its case system, but fossils survive in the personal pronouns and the relative. So we have he nominative, him accusative, and his possessive (genitive in many languages). Who is nominative, whom is accusative, whose possessive. So people who think the grammar of English ought to work according to the rules of Latin (Ancient Greek is actually too loose to serve as a model for excessive precision) therefore say that your sentence ought to be “It was he.” What this ignores is that the forms are also governed by other rules besides case— in particular, when a personal pronoun is the complement of the verb to be. Anybody who answers the question “Who’s that?” with “It is I” is either making a joke, or is too hung-up to be worth bothering with. If you just consider French for a moment: “Qui là?”; no one would dream of telling a French person that “C’est moi” is not correct and they ought to say, “C’est je.” French isn’t English, of course, but English isn’t Latin either, and this is an example of the sort of rule that applies in real English, only it’s paralleled in another language where no one is in denial. As it happens, over about the last ten years what’s left of a case system in English has gone into rapid and terminal decline. You’ll have noticed the people who think that “whom” is a fancy form of “who”, and use it where it’s not at all appropriate by any kind of grammatical analysis. More recently the personal pronouns are going. When I was in Primary School (or perhaps even earlier, when I was a Mixed Infant) we were taught that it was BAD to begin a sentence with “I”. So if you wanted to say you’d gone to a rave with a friend, you said “She and I went to the club.” The “rule” still seems to be around, but instead of changing the order to avoid the dreaded I-at-the-beginning-of-a-sentence, people now say and write “Me”: so we get “Me and her went to the club.” Of course, my teeth itch when I hear or see this, but it’s clearly the way English is going, and it’s to be found in quite educated users. And I rather fancy that in slack moments, I might do it myself. Since the case system of English has been hanging on by its fingertips since the fourteenth century, it’s not surprising it’s finally going. Language changes all the time. The only problem for you is that in some possible extensions of your sentence, “him” would not be elegant. “It was him” is clearly right in answer to a question: “Who did it?” “It was him” (indicating the guilty party); “Was it George who did it?” “It was him.” But suppose you’re not answering a question, and you want to specify what was done: “George did it. It was him who put the Darjeeling in the Assam container.” Some people might object to that, and I might, too, in some moods—I think you’d need to put a lot of stress on “him” with a pause after it. On the other hand, “It was he who put the Darjeeling in the wrong container” will make you look as though you’ve spent too long in an expensive language school that wasn’t worth the money. I would work my way round it one way or another. “It was George who put the Darjeeling in the wrong container.” “George did it. He was the infernal blighter who mixed up the teas.” But if in doubt, I’d say “It was him who did it” with a look in my eyes that would say “I have a First in English from Oxford, and a PhD in Medieval Literature, so what are you going to do about it?”
